Posts.Content: M husband's biopsy was done yesterday in Texas, within hours he was on a plane to NY on business. He will get the results on Wed as he doesn't return until Tues evening. He is saying it's no big issue but I'm keeping fingers crossed jut in case.
Posts.Title: Husband's biopsy done yesterday

Posts.Content: His most recent psa a week ago was 4.2, a few weeks earlier it was 4.1 and a year ago it was 3.0. The biopsy Thurs was uneventful, it was done in Houston and hours after the biopsy he was on a plane to New York. No discomfort and no bleeding. He will meet with the doctor and get the results on Wed. TW
Posts.Title: Husband's biopsy done yesterday

Posts.Content: He is 55 and nothing irregular was mentioned
Posts.Title: Husband's biopsy done yesterday

Posts.Content: I agree with spouse, most doctors have themselves enveloped in iron clad forms that the patient signs prior to surgery. They really had no choice as sueing people in this country has become a favorite past time. I would suggest you read all the forms your father signed before proceeding, it could save you a lot of money.

Posts.Title: considering sueing surgeon

Posts.Content: Unfortunately my husband does have prostate cancer. He has taken a couple of weeks off to relax, and then he will research the best doctors inside and outside the country to look after him, with hopefully little distraction from his normal life. He expects the interview process to take a month especially if he needs to travel outside the country. In the meantime we are doing some overnight trips and stocking up on putting sex in the bank in case it takes a little while to get rolling again. Lydia
Posts.Title: Update on Husbands Biopsy

Posts.Content: regress you may want to qualify your questions , especially the ones where you requested a %, by asking: "as compared to the average of surgeons doing this procedure. Same with how many surgeries he has done..as compared to what? 1,000 surgeries may seem like a lot but if the average is 3,000 the number means something different. TW

Posts.Title: Questions for Surgeon

Posts.Content: I am new to this site, I am here to get an opinion about my husband's care. In a nut shell his psa has risen and is a cause for concern. His ex fianc√© who is an oncologist has come from San Diego to attend our meeting with his urologist(he invited her)It appears he will be having a biopsy done next week to determine if he has pc. In my opinion she is sitting to far forward in her seat and trying to take charge of his care to the point of suggesting if he does have pc then he should ignore surgery and opt for radiation treatment(her area of expertise). I have told my husband we should take no action until w meet with 2 surgeons and discuss a course of action if it turns out he has pc. I think most men have the surgery versus radiation for treatment of pc, am I right in this assumption or is radiation more often the choice, and are there hard numbers available to compare somewhere? TW
Posts.Title: Am I over reacting?
